title: Famiglie divise, spinte allâ€™esodo: il Natale triste e incerto dei cristiani in Medio Oriente- Corriere.it
text: Il Natale richiama, nellâ€™immaginario cristiano, Betlemme, dove Ã¨ nato GesÃ¹ e, in senso largo, le terre delle origini cristiane. Cosâ€™Ã¨ oggi Betlemme per i cristiani? Chi sono i cristiani in Medio Oriente? Nonostante la condizione di minoranza, per secoli sono rimasti abbarbicati a quelle terre: Betlemme e Gerusalemme, Antiochia, dove per la prima volta furono detti cristiani, Damasco, dove Paolo iniziÃ² la sua predicazione e tanti altri luoghi dâ€™Oriente. Passati attraverso il dominio ottomano, come dhimmi, protetti ma allo stesso tempo discriminati, sono stati una componente chiave nel mosaico etnico-religioso mediorientale. Non erano pochi. Nel 1914, la Palestina contava 600.000 musulmani, 80.000 cristiani, 60.000 ebrei. In Siria, i cristiani erano di piÃ¹: il 20% dopo la prima guerra e il 14% nel 1948. Il Natale triste e incerto dei cristiani in Medio Oriente: famiglie divise, spinte allâ€™esodo Travolti dalla Storia, dalla Terra Santa allâ€™Iraq dove luminarie e feste sono state vietate [Oggi a Betlemme câ€™Ã¨ un clima triste, come ha scritto Cremonesi ](https://www.corriere.it/esteri/23_dicembre_22/natale-guerra-betlemme-912655d0-a046-11ee-b1cc-35e5cecb801b.shtml)su questo giornale. Nessun pellegrino. Nonostante il sindaco palestinese sia sempre cristiano, i suoi correligionari sono meno del 10%, mentre nel 1950 erano lâ€™86%. Câ€™Ã¨ un clima diverso con la maggioranza musulmana. Il muro costruito da Israele rende difficili le comunicazioni tra territori palestinesi. Le famiglie sono divise: alcuni nei territori, altri a Gaza. Assai dura, per la guerra, Ã¨ la situazione delle comunitÃ  cristiana di Gaza, meno di 3.000 persone: 700 rifugiate nella chiesa cattolica Sacra Famiglia (qui sono state uccise due cristiane dai cecchini israeliani) e 500 nella chiesa ortodossa di San Porfirio (antico vescovo di Gaza del V secolo), dove sono morte 18 persone per un raid israeliano. I cristiani sono a disagio nellâ€™ambiente dominato da Hamas, ma non Ã¨ facile lasciare Gaza. In tutto il Medio Oriente sono spinti allâ€™esodo. Trentâ€™anni fa, un diplomatico francese, con lo pseudonimo di Jean-Pierre Valognes, scrisse un libro pensoso, Â«Vita e morte dei cristiani dâ€™OrienteÂ». Allora câ€™era incertezza sul futuro. Oggi si intravvede la fine. Non solo in Terra Santa. Lâ€™Iraq, mai ricostruitosi come Stato dopo le guerre, Ã¨ insicuro. I cristiani hanno subito gli attacchi di Daesh nelle loro terre storiche. Sono scesi dal 4 allâ€™1% degli iracheni. I caduti non sono mancati. Di recente il patriarca caldeo, Sako, si Ã¨ visto ritirare il decreto di nomina dal presidente iracheno, che anche i sultani ottomani concedevano ai suoi predecessori. Addirittura, nel 1900, una squadra navale francese fece una dimostrazione militare, perchÃ© la Sublime Porta tardava a concedere il decreto al patriarca caldeo di allora. Oggi, senza decreto, Sako, non puÃ² disporre del patrimonio della Chiesa. Sembrava un caso isolato, ma il provvedimento Ã¨ stato esteso a tutti i vescovi. Il patriarca ha denunciato Â«lâ€™appropriazione delle risorse dei cristianiÂ» e il Â«sistematico cambiamento demografico delle loro cittÃ  nella Piana di NiniveÂ». I regimi Baath, in Iraq e Siria hanno esercitato una Â«protezioneÂ» sui cristiani. Oggi si apre la caccia alle proprietÃ  loro e delle Chiese (non sempre ben gestite in Medio Oriente): Ã¨ un capitolo rilevante. Nella strage dei cristiani durante la Prima guerra mondiale, lâ€™appropriazione dei loro beni incrementÃ² il consenso. In Siria, gli emissari del regime impongono taglie ai cristiani abbienti. Le sopraffazioni favoriscono lâ€™esodo, ingrossato pure dai giovani cristiani che rifiutano il lungo servizio militare. La guerra e lâ€™illegalitÃ  mostrano come il favore del regime Â«laicoÂ» del presidente Assad verso i cristiani, nonostante lâ€™atteggiamento sottomesso dei patriarchi al sistema, funzioni poco, specie con lâ€™arbitrio diffuso. Il Libano, tradizionale terra di libertÃ  per i cristiani dâ€™Oriente, resta solo un passaggio per gli esodi, a causa della grave crisi economica e politica. Qui i cristiani sono numerosi (nel 2018 erano stimati il 34%, ma oggi sono meno), ma il futuro Ã¨ incerto per tutti in un Paese fragile. Natale triste per i cristiani. In Iraq, il patriarca Sako ha vietato luminarie e feste in segno di lutto e protesta. Andrea Santoro, prete romano ucciso in Turchia nel 2006, diceva agli amici occidentali, dopo una visita ad alcune languenti comunitÃ  in Medio Oriente: Â«Non fate morire il cristianesimo, non riducetelo a osservanza e convenevoliÂ». Il cristianesimo infatti puÃ² essere travolto dalla storia, ma fanno la differenza anche le scelte dei cristiani e delle Chiese nella transizione epocale del nostro tempo. In Oriente, ma anche in Occidente. Il cardinale Martini osservava inquieto: Â«la storia Ã¨ seria ed Ã¨ affidata a noiÂ». title: Tencent's AI Restraint Shows Risk of Alibaba, JD Food War
text:
(Bloomberg) -- Chinaâ€™s biggest tech companies are bouncing back after years on the ropes with outsized ambitions to dominate in everything from robots and smart glasses to cheap meals. But investors want them to focus their spending where it counts â€” AI.
From Meta Platforms Inc. to Google, one topic has dominated the conversation this tech earnings season: how Silicon Valleyâ€™s leaders will invest to seize the momentum in a game-changing technology. In China, the industry is just as enthralled by a three-way battle to deliver the cheapest meals and knick-knacks, fastest. That conflict between Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., JD.com Inc. and Meituan â€” both on social media and in the physical consumer arena â€” isnâ€™t just compressing margins and irking investors â€” itâ€™s risking Beijingâ€™s scrutiny.
So far this year JD, Alibaba and Meituan have pledged or spent billions of dollars hiring delivery people, creating coupons and plying their millions of daily users with advertising about free milk tea and other instant retail promotions. Investors responded with a sell-off in Meituan and JD, the most exposed to the price war, shedding around a combined $100 billion in market value since late last year. Things came to a head last month when the industry regulator called all three into a private meeting to lay down the law. And days later, the trio coordinated contrite statements promising to end â€œdisorderly competition.â€
But in reality, theyâ€™ve no choice but to keep going, analysts say, because theyâ€™re essentially fighting for the lifeblood of their business: users. With AI still years away from monetization, thatâ€™s become the central existential problem to China Tech Inc.
â€œWe want less food delivery wars, and more reasons to be optimistic about AI monetization,â€ said Vey-Sern Ling, managing director at Union Bancaire Privee. â€œUltimately for tech companies to perform they have to deliver top line growth. Progress on the monetization of AI is one way â€” whether directly, such as through the provision of cloud services or indirectly by enhancing their respective core businesses.â€
After years of regulatory scrutiny and Covid-era disruption, the countryâ€™s biggest tech firms are once again ramping up deals and competing fiercely for users to propel growth. Investors have piled into Chinaâ€™s tech resurgence over the past year, betting on the countryâ€™s biggest firms after a rapprochement with President Xi Jinpingâ€™s government in February. Those companies are still trading far below their peak. The food wars didnâ€™t help. One outlier however has been Tencent â€” itâ€™s outperformed its biggest peers this summer.
Tencent on Wednesday kicked off earnings season for Chinaâ€™s big tech with revenue that beat estimates and a plan for prudence in AI spending, despite faster-than-anticipated growth across its gaming and advertising businesses. Its shares rose as much as 2.4% in Hong Kong on Thursday, reaching their highest level in more than four years.
JD made a sudden foray into food delivery in February, sparking a price war with Alibaba and market leader Meituan. Itâ€™s what Morgan Stanley refers to as the â€œprisonerâ€™s dilemmaâ€ â€” three heavyweights locked in a seemingly irrational conflict, none willing to blink first. After making early progress, JD is struggling to attract new users and investors are clamoring for clues about the direction behind the spending spree.
â€œItâ€™s very difficult to guess what JD wants to do. Theyâ€™ve been all over the place doing various things, trying to spend a lot of money, but we do not know what they want to achieve,â€ said Roxy Wong, senior portfolio manager at BNP Paribas Asset Management Asia Ltd. â€œAll of a sudden theyâ€™re doing everything at the same time.â€
Alibabaâ€™s margins are expected to take a toll from its massive spending plans, which include splashing $52 billion on AI infrastructure and forking out $7 billion on food delivery subsidies. Investors are also asking tough questions about its strategy.
â€œFor Alibaba, food delivery business may not be that important, but when it comes to the battle, they cannot retreat,â€ said Li Chengdong, head of Beijing-based internet think-tank Haitun. â€œWhile the recent huge spending is definitely not what investors are keen to see, Alibabaâ€™s investment in AI remains an uncertainty as well as the current investment may not necessarily yield results.â€
Meituan is enjoying fresh momentum off the back of a partnership with Kuaishou, a Chinese live-streaming platform. But like JD itâ€™s getting distracted at home as it looks to build an empire abroad. The companyâ€™s successful Keeta app in Hong Kong has set a template for overseas moves. It launched in Saudi Arabia last September and according to Chinese media outlet LatePost, itâ€™s now eyeing expansion into Qatar, Kuwait, Oman and Bahrain over the next three years.
â€œThe competition will stop when everyone returns to normal business judgment and rationality,â€ Wang Puzhong, head of local commerce at Meituan, told LatePost last month. â€œRight now we are all in a state of irrational excitement.â€

title: Argentina to file complaint after controversial Paris Olympics football debut
text: The Argentine Football Association (AFA) announced it will present a complaint in front of FIFAâ€™s Disciplinary Committee, following the events at the Albicelesteâ€™s debut in the 2024 Paris Olympics. In a communiquÃ© released on Wednesday, AFA stated that the complaint was aimed at ensuring that â€œthe necessary sanctions for such a serious issueâ€ were passed, adding that these disciplinary measures were â€œrequired to guarantee the safety of the players in order to play football.â€ On Wednesday, the Argentine Olympic football team got a last-minute 2-2 tie in its debut against Morocco. Immediately after the goal, the match was suspended when Moroccan fans invaded the pitch and set off a loud firecracker, which caused the Argentine players to run back to their locker room. The game was seemingly over and the end result was confirmed on the Olympics official site. But then images confirming an off-side position during Argentinaâ€™s final play were seen in the official broadcast, leading to the referee announcing that the game would be resumed. Argentinaâ€™s case is that under FIFA regulations â€” the rules under which all professional games are played â€” the game shouldnâ€™t have been resumed following the pitch invasion and that the goal shouldnâ€™t have been disallowed. AFA president Claudio Tapia took to X to give his views on the incident, which he labeled â€œregrettableâ€. â€œWaiting almost two hours in the dressing rooms after a pitch invasion and the violence the Argentine team suffered, and then making our players go back and warm up to play in a game that shouldâ€™ve been suspended, was a nonsensical decision that goes against the rules of the game,â€ wrote Tapia. After the game, which ended in a 2-1 Morocco win, Argentina head coach Javier Mascherano called the events â€œthe biggest circus Iâ€™ve seen in my lifeâ€ and insisted that neither his players nor the Moroccans wished to continue playing. Contacted by the Herald, the Argentine Olympic Committee (COA) said it had â€œno commentâ€ on the matter.

title: New Zealand vs Bangladesh 2nd T20I called-off due to incessant rain
text: Mount Maunganui: Rain washed out the second Twenty20 international between New Zealand and Bangladesh after only 11 overs Friday, leaving Bangladesh with a 1-0 lead in the three-match series. The match began on time and New Zealand was 72-2 after 11 overs when the heavy rain which had fallen throughout the day in this seaside city returned to Bay Oval. title: Smart Spending with Tech: Apps and Platforms to Help You Save Money
text:
Introduction
In todayâ€™s fast-paced digital era, technology has become an integral part of our daily lives, transforming the way we manage our finances. From budgeting to finding the best deals, numerous apps and platforms are designed to make smart spending a seamless and efficient process. In this article, weâ€™ll explore the world of financial technology and delve into the innovative apps and platforms that can empower you to save money intelligently.
Budgeting Made Simple
Managing your finances starts with
effective budgeting, and thereâ€™s no shortage of apps to assist you in this endeavor. One standout application is Mint, a comprehensive budgeting tool that syncs with your bank accounts to provide a real-time overview of your financial landscape. Mint categorizes your transactions, tracks your spending patterns, and even suggests personalized
budgets based on your habits.
Another noteworthy mention is YNAB (You Need A Budget), which adopts a proactive approach to budgeting. YNAB focuses on giving every dollar a job, ensuring that each penny is allocated towards a specific purpose. With its user-friendly interface and educational resources, YNAB not only helps you control your spending but also cultivates a proactive financial mindset.
Hunting for Discounts and Deals
Saving money often involves finding the best deals and discounts, and technology has made this task more accessible than ever. Honey, a browser extension and mobile app, automatically scans the web for the best coupon codes during online shopping. With a single click, Honey applies the most lucrative discounts to your cart, maximizing your savings effortlessly.
For those who prefer in-store shopping, Rakuten (formerly Ebates) offers cashback on purchases made through its platform. Simply link your credit card to Rakuten, and youâ€™ll earn cash back at participating retailers. The accrued cashback can then be transferred to your bank account or redeemed as gift cards, providing you with tangible savings on your everyday expenses.
Streamlining Investments
Investing is a crucial aspect of wealth-building, and technology has democratized access to the world of investing. Robo-advisors like Wealthfront and Betterment leverage algorithms to create and manage a diversified investment
portfolio tailored to your financial goals and risk tolerance. These platforms automate the investment process, rebalance your portfolio, and optimize for tax efficiency, all while charging lower fees compared to traditional financial advisors.
Additionally, micro-investing apps like Acorns round up your everyday purchases to the nearest dollar and invest the spare change. This hands-off approach allows you to incrementally grow your investment portfolio without feeling a significant impact on your daily spending habits.
Cutting Subscription Costs
Subscription services have become ubiquitous, from streaming platforms to fitness apps. To save money on these recurring expenses, consider leveraging apps like Truebill. Truebill analyzes your bank statements, identifies your subscriptions, and provides an easy-to-read overview of your monthly charges. With a single tap, you can cancel or negotiate lower rates for unwanted subscriptions, putting you in control of your recurring expenses.
Smart Banking for Smart Spending
Traditional banking is evolving, thanks to the emergence of fintech disruptors. Online banks such as Chime and Ally offer fee-free banking with features like early direct deposit and high-interest savings accounts. By eliminating unnecessary fees, these banks empower you to keep more of your hard-earned money.
Moreover, budget-centric banking apps like Simple prioritize transparency and ease of use. Simpleâ€™s intuitive interface allows you to set savings goals, track your expenses, and even schedule expenses for future dates. With features designed to simplify your financial life, these apps redefine the banking experience and put you in the driverâ€™s seat of your finances.
Embracing Cashback Rewards
Cashback rewards programs have gained popularity, and technology has taken them to new heights. Apps like Dosh and Rakuten (mentioned earlier for in-store cashback) offer cashback on everyday purchases. Dosh, in particular, stands out by seamlessly linking to your credit or debit cards and automatically earning you cashback when you make qualifying purchases.
By integrating these cashback apps into your spending routine, you can passively accumulate savings over time. Whether itâ€™s dining out, booking hotels, or shopping online, these apps turn your everyday expenses into opportunities to earn money back.
Conclusion
Navigating the landscape of personal finance has never been more accessible, thanks to the myriad of apps and platforms designed to facilitate smart spending. From budgeting tools that provide real-time insights into your financial habits to cashback apps that reward you for your everyday purchases, technology is reshaping the way we approach money management.
As you embark on your
 journey towards financial wellness, consider integrating these apps and platforms into your routine. Whether youâ€™re a seasoned investor looking to optimize your portfolio or a budget-conscious consumer seeking the best deals, the tech-driven solutions outlined in this article offer a diverse array of options to suit your financial needs.

title: Labor absenteeism continues to grow: almost a million and a half people missing work in 2024 every day
text:
Claudia T. Ferrero
Madrid
03/27/2025
Updated at 14: 16h.
â€œLabor absenteeism, and especially that not justified by a temporary disability, remains at high levels, which impacts very negatively on the productivity and competitiveness of companies,â€ says ValentÃ­n Bote, director of Randstad Research. Since the end of 2022, the level of absenteeism remains above 6% and since the end of 2023 the absenteeism by IT exceeds 5%. Thus, the number of employees who on average did not attend their workplace every day in 2023 reached 1,463,544 of which 1,137,500 were on a medical leave, according to the â€˜Labor Ability report | Fourth quarter 2024 â€˜published today by Randstad.
Worrying figures if compared to the results obtained a year ago, registering at the close of 2024 increases of 6% and 5% of the number of people who were absent from their working day in a general way and by IT, respectively, as indicated by the report. In the Spanish labor market as a whole, of the 1.46 million employees that are missing every day to their job, more than 326,000 people do so for reasons other than a medical decline, that is, 22.2% do not have a temporary disability For medical reasons.
According to these data, general absenteeism has caused a Loss of 6.7% of the agreed hours which represents a tenth rebound regarding the data registered one year earlier. For absenteeism due to temporary disability (IT) or with medical leave, the fourth quarter rate was 5.2%, two tenths higher than the one accounted for in the fourth quarter of last year.
The industry, the sector most affected by work absenteeism
The industry It is the sector that, at the end of 2024, is positioned at the head in absenteeism in the whole country, by concentrating the highest number of workers who do not go to their job, adding 7.2% of the agreed hours. Among the other two major economic sectors, the sector services with 6.7%, it stands behind industry, and, thirdly, the construction It remains with the lowest rate, with 5.6%.
